Package tage.JmeBullet

Class JmeBulletPhysicsEngine

java.lang.Object
tage.JmeBullet.JmeBulletPhysicsEngine
public class JmeBulletPhysicsEngine extends Object
This class provides an implementation of the PhysicsEngine interface using the JBullet physics engine.
If using TAGE, this physics engine is automatically instantiated.
Author:
Russell Bolles, John Clevenger (JavaDoc), Oscar Solorzano

  • Constructor Details

    • JmeBulletPhysicsEngine

  • Method Details

    • initSystem

      public void initSystem()
      #initSystem() initializes the underlying physics engine, providing an (empty) "physics world" along with a default collision handler, collision dispatcher, and constraint solver. The default physics world extents are {-10,000 ... 10,000} in each of X, Y, and Z; object locations should be constrained to these bounds for proper physics calculations. The implementation's default gravity vector in the physics world is [0,0,0] (meaning gravity is turned off by default). Note that this means the implementation does not use the DEFAULT_GRAVITY constants defined in PhysicsEngine.

    • setGravity

      public void setGravity(float[] grav)
      Sets the gravity vector for the physics world to the specified [x,y,z] vector.

    • removeObject

      public void removeObject(int uid)
      Removes the PhysicsObject with the specified UID from the physics world, if it exists in the world. This method has no effect if no object with the specified UID exists in the physics world.

    • update

      public void update(float seconds)
      Forces the physics world to advance (that is, steps the physics simulation) by the specified amount of time, given in nanoseconds.

    • nextUID

      public int nextUID()
      Returns a unique ID used to identify physics objects.

    • detectCollisions

      public void detectCollisions()
      Call once every frame to detect collisions for all objects Results are stored in an arraylist per physics object
